Expectation1: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation1: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I stared at my screen, the clock ticking closer to 8:00 AM. My code was almost done, the new feature finally coming together after a week of late nights. But the code review comments blinked at me: “Performance issues—needs refactoring.” I knew I couldn’t just push it as is; my team counted on me to deliver clean, efficient code. Yet, my phone buzzed with a reminder: I was the only volunteer scheduled to unlock the community center at 8:15. People would already be waiting outside, some of them elderly, relying on me to start the morning service. My manager expected me to fix the code before the daily standup, but the faces of those waiting volunteers flashed in my mind. My heart pounded as I weighed the demands—my team’s trust in my work, the community’s trust in my presence. I felt pulled in two directions, the pressure mounting as the minutes slipped away.
